articles.headline: The New Money Rules for Recent Graduates
articles.snippet: While you were in class, some laws and regulations were approved that may change your (financial) life.
articles.abstract: While you were in class, some laws and regulations were approved that may change your (financial) life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Graduation season is a time of oddly mixed emotions for the people finishing college and graduate school. On the one hand, there is pride in a job well done (or relief at simply getting through) and the satisfaction of having finished a long, hard slog. On the other, there is primal fear. Will anyone pay me to do something I’m good at? And will I actually have enough money to live on?

articles.headline: Marcos Seeks to Restore Philippine Dynasty
articles.snippet: The former first lady of the Philippines is battling to restore the Marcos name in coming elections.
articles.abstract: The former first lady of the Philippines is battling to restore the Marcos name in coming elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: BATAC, the Philippines — At a mall food court here, where she was sitting with reporters covering her campaign for the House of Representatives, Imelda Marcos inserted iPod earbuds on either side of her bouffant coiffure.

articles.headline: The Trades of a Lifetime in 20 Minutes
articles.snippet: By luck, savvy or lightning speed, there were gobs of money to be made from the bargains that came and went in an instant on Thursday.
articles.abstract: By luck, savvy or lightning speed, there were gobs of money to be made from the bargains that came and went in an instant on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Someone on Wall Street just made a killing.

articles.headline: Origin of Wall Street’s Plunge Continues to Elude Officials
articles.snippet: Officials from federal agencies hunted for clues amid a tangle of electronic trading records to find out what caused Thursday’s near panic on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Officials from federal agencies hunted for clues amid a tangle of electronic trading records to find out what caused Thursday’s near panic on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after a harrowing plunge in the stock market, federal regulators were still unable on Friday to answer the one question on every investor’s mind: What caused that near panic on Wall Street?

articles.headline: Workers on Oil Rig Recall a Terrible Night of Blasts
articles.snippet: Men snapped into action after a blast from natural gas rocked the oil rig Deepwater Horizon.
articles.abstract: Men snapped into action after a blast from natural gas rocked the oil rig Deepwater Horizon.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Nearly 50 miles offshore at the big oil rig floating on a glassy-calm sea, a helicopter landed early on the morning of April 20, carrying four executives from BP, the oil company. The men were visiting the Deepwater Horizon to help honor the crew for its standout safety record.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and Justin Gillis

articles.headline: Democrats See Hopes for West Dim in Colorado
articles.snippet: A sluggish economy, a high foreclosure rate, the rising federal budget deficit and opposition to the health care law have all contributed to a challenge for Democrats.
articles.abstract: A sluggish economy, a high foreclosure rate, the rising federal budget deficit and opposition to the health care law have all contributed to a challenge for Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — When Barack Obama stood before an admiring audience at Mile High Stadium here and accepted his presidential nomination 21 months ago, Democratic leaders crowed about turning Colorado into a reliable stronghold, another step toward building the party’s strength in the West.

articles.headline: Imam’s Path From Condemning Terror to Preaching Jihad
articles.snippet: Anwar al-Awlaki, a U.S.-born cleric, has become a central figure in the luring of Western Muslims to violent extremism.
articles.abstract: Anwar al-Awlaki, a U.S.-born cleric, has become a central figure in the luring of Western Muslims to violent extremism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, the eloquent 30-year-old imam of a mosque outside Washington became a go-to Muslim cleric for reporters scrambling to explain Islam. He condemned the mass murder, invited television crews to follow him around and patiently explained the rituals of his religion.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: That Pill You Took? It May Well Be Theirs
articles.snippet: Teva has secured its climb through aggressive acquisitions, quality control, low prices and a devotion to corporate frugality.
articles.abstract: Teva has secured its climb through aggressive acquisitions, quality control, low prices and a devotion to corporate frugality.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Wales, Pa.

articles.headline: You’d Never Know He’s a Sun King
articles.snippet: After years of quietly investing nearly $1 billion in environmental companies and causes, David Gelbaum talks about putting his chips on solar energy.
articles.abstract: After years of quietly investing nearly $1 billion in environmental companies and causes, David Gelbaum talks about putting his chips on solar energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

articles.headline: Ignoring the Elephant in the Bailout
articles.snippet: All of the chatter about financial reform overlooks Freddie Mac’s horrific first quarter, and its warning that credit losses are likely to keep growing this year.
articles.abstract: All of the chatter about financial reform overlooks Freddie Mac’s horrific first quarter, and its warning that credit losses are likely to keep growing this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you blinked, you might have missed the ugly first-quarter report last week from Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giant that, along with its sister Fannie Mae, soldiers on as one of the financial world’s biggest wards of the state.

articles.headline: Greek Debt Woes Ripple Outward, From Asia to U.S.
articles.snippet: The fear that began in Athens, raced through Europe and finally shook the stock market in the U.S. is now affecting the broader global economy.
articles.abstract: The fear that began in Athens, raced through Europe and finally shook the stock market in the U.S. is now affecting the broader global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fear that began in Athens, raced through Europe and finally shook the stock market in the United States is now affecting the broader global economy, from the ability of Asian corporations to raise money to the outlook for money-market funds where American savers park their cash.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Eric Dash

articles.headline: New Setback in Attempt to Contain Gulf Oil Spill
articles.snippet: A containment dome had been placed over one of the leaks, but crews discovered that the dome was clogging, forcing them to move it aside and allow oil to keep gushing.
articles.abstract: A containment dome had been placed over one of the leaks, but crews discovered that the dome was clogging, forcing them to move it aside and allow oil to keep gushing.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROBERT, La. — The latest effort to contain the oil spill that has poured millions of gallons of crude into the Gulf of Mexico encountered a setback 5,000 feet underwater, officials said Saturday, meaning oil will continue gushing into the ocean for at least several more days, and possibly months.

articles.headline: E.U. Details $957 Billion Rescue Package
articles.snippet: European leaders agreed to provide a huge rescue package to regain lost credibility with investors, and early reaction from world markets was positive.
articles.abstract: European leaders agreed to provide a huge rescue package to regain lost credibility with investors, and early reaction from world markets was positive.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders agreed on Monday to provide a huge rescue package of nearly $1 trillion in a sweeping effort to combat the debt crisis that has engulfed Europe and threatened markets around the world.
articles.byline: By James Kanter and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Holder Backs a Miranda Limit for Terror Suspects
articles.snippet:
Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. proposed carving
a broad new exception to Miranda rights as he asserted that the Times Square bomb suspect trained in Pakistan.
articles.abstract:
Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. proposed carving
a broad new exception to Miranda rights as he asserted that the Times Square bomb suspect trained in Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Sunday it would seek a law allowing investigators to interrogate terrorism suspects without informing them of their rights, as Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. flatly asserted that the defendant in the Times Square bombing attempt was trained by the Taliban in Pakistan.

articles.headline: Imagine YouTube for Traders
articles.snippet: Thomson Reuters’s new product, Reuters Insider, is a service that captures myriad streams of information produced by the company’s reporters and partners.
articles.abstract: Thomson Reuters’s new product, Reuters Insider, is a service that captures myriad streams of information produced by the company’s reporters and partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: For half an hour last Thursday afternoon, CNBC was the most exciting place on television. Watching Erin Burnett and Jim Cramer try not to freak out — they acquitted themselves nicely — while the market tumbled like a drunken rag doll down a long staircase was amazing television.

articles.headline: Celebrity Guest Hosts Find Fans, and Some Fun, in ‘Raw’s’ Ring
articles.snippet: Buzz Aldrin, Jewel, and Donald Trump are among the boldface names that have hosted World Wrestling Entertainment’s “Raw.”
articles.abstract: Buzz Aldrin, Jewel, and Donald Trump are among the boldface names that have hosted World Wrestling Entertainment’s “Raw.”
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Will Forte, Ryan Phillippe and Kristen Wiig were looking to promote the forthcoming comedy “MacGruber,” they made an early visit not to Jay Leno or David Letterman, but a live prime-time program with an audience bigger than that of either of their shows, as well as “The View” and “Ellen.”

articles.headline: In Mobile Age, Sound Quality Steps Back
articles.snippet: With the ease of loading music onto an iPod, a generation of fans has been happily trading fidelity for portability.
articles.abstract: With the ease of loading music onto an iPod, a generation of fans has been happily trading fidelity for portability.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the ripe age of 28, Jon Zimmer is sort of an old fogey. That is, he is obsessive about the sound quality of his music.

articles.headline: Computer Trades Are Focus in Wall Street Plunge
articles.snippet: Investigators said they were looking at how a controlled slowdown in trading, meant to bring about stability, set off uncontrolled selling.
articles.abstract: Investigators said they were looking at how a controlled slowdown in trading, meant to bring about stability, set off uncontrolled selling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investigators seeking an explanation for the brief stock market panic last week said Sunday that they were focusing increasingly on how a controlled slowdown in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, meant to bring about stability, instead set off uncontrolled selling on electronic exchanges.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Edward Wyatt

articles.headline: Banks Lobbying Against Derivatives Trading Ban
articles.snippet: The banking industry has set aside most of its top concerns about a financial overhaul to focus on a provision that would require banks to end derivatives trading.
articles.abstract: The banking industry has set aside most of its top concerns about a financial overhaul to focus on a provision that would require banks to end derivatives trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cory Strupp, who represents Wall Street in Washington, spent the last six months lobbying for more than two dozen changes in the derivatives chapter of the Senate’s financial legislation.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Consensus for Limits to Secrecy at the Fed
articles.snippet: For the Fed’s chairman, who has made it a priority to preserve the independence of monetary policy, a proposal gaining steam in the Senate is a partial victory.
articles.abstract: For the Fed’s chairman, who has made it a priority to preserve the independence of monetary policy, a proposal gaining steam in the Senate is a partial victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve appears to have succeeded in fending off a challenge to the autonomy of its monetary policy decisions, but it is likely to face greater scrutiny of the actions it has taken since 2007 to prevent financial institutions from collapsing.

articles.headline: An Indie That Believes in CDs
articles.snippet: While many labels are shrinking or fighting to survive, the Concord Music Group has concentrated on what it calls the adult audience.
articles.abstract: While many labels are shrinking or fighting to survive, the Concord Music Group has concentrated on what it calls the adult audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: The waters might be choppy for the music business right now, but the Concord Music Group is happy to ride those waves.

articles.headline: At Front Lines, AIDS War Is Falling Apart
articles.snippet: Uganda is the first and most obvious example of how the war on AIDS is falling apart as cases rise and global  priorities shift.
articles.abstract: Uganda is the first and most obvious example of how the war on AIDS is falling apart as cases rise and global  priorities shift.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — On the grounds of Uganda’s biggest AIDS clinic, Dinavance Kamukama sits under a tree and weeps.

articles.headline: Obama Picks Kagan as Justice Nominee
articles.snippet: After a monthlong search, President Obama named Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the 112th justice of the Supreme Court.
articles.abstract: After a monthlong search, President Obama named Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the 112th justice of the Supreme Court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama nominated Solicitor General Elena Kagan as the nation’s 112th justice, choosing his own chief advocate before the Supreme Court to join it in ruling on cases critical to his view of the country’s future.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Europe Officials Move to Carry Out Aid Package
articles.snippet: Central banks began buying euro-zone bonds — an unprecedented move to inject cash into the system.
articles.abstract: Central banks began buying euro-zone bonds — an unprecedented move to inject cash into the system.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — European officials on Monday took steps to tackle the widening sovereign debt crisis that has destabilized the Continent.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and James Kanter

articles.headline: Stocks Soar After Europe Announces Rescue Plan
articles.snippet: Markets rebound after European leaders and major central banks announced an array of emergency lending measures.
articles.abstract: Markets rebound after European leaders and major central banks announced an array of emergency lending measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a day, at least, investors could exhale.
